prompt: I have pork belly, garlic, and chili oil. I want to make something spicy and Sichuan-style.
pairs: [('pork belly', '500g pork belly cut into 1-inch cubes'), ('garlic', '4 cloves garlic minced'), ('chili oil', '2 tablespoons chili oil plus extra for serving')]
raw_output:
```json
{
  "recipe_name": "Spicy Sichuan Pork Belly with Garlic and Chili Oil",
  "chosen_from": "User Request and Common Sichuan Recipes",
  "ingredients": [
    "500g pork belly, cut into 1-inch cubes",
    "2 tablespoons chili oil, plus extra for serving",
    "4 cloves garlic, minced",
    "1 tablespoon light soy sauce",
    "1 tablespoon dark soy sauce",
    "1 tablespoon Shaoxing wine (or dry sherry)",
    "1 teaspoon Sichuan peppercorns, toasted and ground",
    "1/2 teaspoon sugar",
    "1/4 cup water or chicken broth",
    "2 scallions, thinly sliced (for garnish)",
    "Cooked rice, for serving"
  ],
  "steps": [
    "In a pot, blanch the pork belly in boiling water for 5 minutes. Drain and rinse under cold water. This helps remove impurities.",
    "Heat 1 tablespoon of chili oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat.",
    "Add the pork belly and stir-fry until lightly browned on all sides, about 5-7 minutes.",
    "Add the minced garlic and stir-fry for another minute until fragrant.",
    "Add light soy sauce, dark soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, ground Sichuan peppercorns, sugar, and water/broth.",
    "Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for about 1-1.5 hours, or until the pork belly is tender. Check periodically and add more water/broth if needed to prevent sticking.",
    "Once the pork belly is tender, increase the heat to medium-high and cook, stirring frequently, until the sauce thickens and glazes the pork belly, about 5 minutes.",
    "Serve hot, drizzled with extra chili oil and garnished with sliced scallions. Serve with cooked rice."
  ]
}
```

prompt: I have chicken thighs, soy sauce, and ginger. I want a simple Chinese home-style dish.

raw_output:

```json
{
  "recipe_name": "Soy Sauce Ginger Chicken Thighs",
  "chosen_from": "Simple pantry ingredients",
  "ingredients": [
    "4-6 chicken thighs",
    "1/4 cup soy sauce",
    "1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger",
    "1 tablespoon cooking oil (vegetable, canola, or peanut)",
    "1/4 cup water",
    "Optional: 1 scallion, thinly sliced (for garnish)"
  ],

    "Pat chicken thighs dry with paper towels.",
    "In a bowl, combine soy sauce and grated ginger.",
    "Marinate chicken thighs in soy sauce mixture for at least 15 minutes (or up to an hour) at room temperature, flipping occasionally.",
    "Heat cooking oil in a skillet or wok over medium-high heat.",
    "Add chicken thighs to the hot skillet, skin-side down. Sear for 4-5 minutes until the skin is golden brown.",
    "Flip chicken thighs and cook for another 3-4 minutes until lightly browned on the other side.",
    "Pour in the marinade and water. Bring to a simmer.",
    "Cover the skillet and reduce heat to low. Simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and tender.",
    "Remove the chicken from the skillet. If desired, simmer the sauce uncovered for a few minutes to thicken slightly.",
    "Serve chicken thighs with the sauce drizzled over them. Garnish with sliced scallions, if using.",
    "Serve with rice."
  ]
}
```

prompt: I have ground pork, napa cabbage, and garlic. I want a northern Chinese dumpling filling idea.
pairs: [('ground pork', '1 pound ground pork'), ('napa cabbage', '1 pound napa cabbage finely chopped and salted'), ('garlic', '4 cloves garlic minced')]
raw_output:
```json
{
  "recipe_name": "Napa Cabbage and Pork Dumplings (Northern Chinese Style)",
  "chosen_from": "User Request",
  "ingredients": [
    "1 pound ground pork",
    "1 pound napa cabbage, finely chopped and salted",
    "4 cloves garlic, minced",
    "2 tablespoons soy sauce",
    "1 tablespoon sesame oil",
    "1 teaspoon ground white pepper",
    "1/2 teaspoon sugar",
    "Dumpling wrappers (store-bought or homemade)",
    "Water for sealing dumplings",
    "Optional: Green onions, finely chopped, for garnish and/or filling"
  ],
  "steps": [
    "Prepare the cabbage: Place the chopped napa cabbage in a colander and sprinkle with 1 teaspoon of salt. Let it sit for at least 30 minutes to release excess water. Then, rinse the cabbage thoroughly and squeeze out as much water as possible. This is crucial for a non-watery filling.",
    "Combine the filling: In a large bowl, combine the ground pork, squeezed napa cabbage, minced garlic, soy sauce, sesame oil, white pepper, and sugar. If using, add green onions now. Mix everything thoroughly with your hands or a spoon until well combined and the mixture becomes sticky.",
    "Prepare the dumplings: Place a dumpling wrapper in your hand or on a clean surface. Place about 1-2 teaspoons of the filling in the center of the wrapper. Dip your finger in water and moisten the edges of the wrapper. Fold the wrapper in half, creating a half-moon shape, and pinch the edges together firmly to seal the dumpling. You can pleat the edges for a more decorative seal if desired.",
    "Cook the dumplings: You can cook the dumplings by boiling, steaming, or pan-frying.  To boil: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Gently add the dumplings and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until they float to the surface and are cooked through. To steam: Place the dumplings in a steamer basket and steam for 8-10 minutes. To pan-fry (potstickers): Heat some oil in a non-stick skillet over medium heat. Place the dumplings in the skillet and cook until the bottoms are golden brown (about 3-4 minutes). Add about 1/2 cup of water to the skillet, cover immediately to create steam, and cook until the water has evaporated and the dumplings are cooked through (about 5-7 minutes).",
    "Serve: Serve the dumplings hot, with dipping sauces of your choice (e.g., soy sauce, vinegar, chili oil)."
  ]
}
```

```json
    "Marinate the pork belly: In a bowl, combine 1 tbsp soy sauce, 1 tsp sugar, and white pepper. Rub this mixture all over the pork belly, including the skin.  Let it marinate for at least 30 minutes.",
    "Fry the pork belly (optional but recommended for flavor and texture): Heat oil in a large pot or wok.  Carefully place the pork belly, skin-side down, in the hot oil. Fry for 3-5 minutes until the skin is golden brown and blistered. Be careful as oil may splatter. Remove the pork belly and set aside.",
    "Sauté aromatics and Mei Cai: In the same pot, remove most of the oil (leave about 1 tbsp). Sauté the minced garlic and ginger until fragrant. Add the dried and squeezed mei cai and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes.",
    "Simmer the pork belly: Slice the pork belly into about 1-inch thick pieces.  Arrange the mei cai at the bottom of a pot or slow cooker.  Place the sliced pork belly on top, skin-side up. Pour in Shaoxing wine, soy sauce, dark soy sauce, sugar, water/broth. Add star anise and cinnamon stick, if using.",
    "Braise the pork belly:  Bring the liquid to a simmer.  Cover and cook on low heat for 2-3 hours, or until the pork belly is very tender (easily pierced with a fork). If using a slow cooker, cook on low for 6-8 hours.",
    "Prepare for Serving: Carefully remove the pork belly from the braising liquid.  Strain the braising liquid, discarding the aromatics.",
     "Serve: Slice the pork belly and arrange it with the mei cai on a plate. Pour some of the reduced braising liquid over the pork belly and mei cai. Serve hot with steamed rice."
  ]
}
```
